questions.text: A 26-year-old conceives on the IUCD. Wants to continue pregnancy. Next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remove the IUCD gently

 

The Ans. is Remove the IUCD gently. When a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUCD should be removed if possible. Leaving the IUCD in situ is associated with risks such as preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and potential fetal anomalies. While removing the IUCD does carry a slightly increased risk of miscarriage, the overall benefits of removal outweigh the risks of leaving it in place. Removal should be done carefully, with appropriate counseling provided to the patient about the potential risks involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leave the IUCD in situ: Leaving the IUCD in place is not recommended as it can lead to complications like preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and other pregnancy complications. Therefore, it should be removed if the patient wishes to continue the pregnancy.

 

Option C. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): MTP is not appropriate in this scenario because the patient wishes to continue with the pregnancy. The focus should be on managing the pregnancy safely with the IUCD removed.

 

Option D. Progesterone support: Progesterone support is not indicated in this case as it does not address the main issue, which is the presence of the IUCD and its associated risks if left in place during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a pregnancy occurs with an IUCD in place and the patient wishes to continue, the IUCD should be removed gently to minimize risks associated with leaving it in situ.

questions.text: Identify the sign that is seen during 8 weeks of pregnancy resulting in a dusky blue color of the vagina: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chadwick's sign

 

Explanation:

 

  • This sign is known as Chadwick’s sign. This sign is bluish discoloration of anterior vaginal wall due to local vascular congestion. It is seen in the 8th week period of gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmer's sign: Regular and rhythmic uterine contractions elicited on bimanual exam, seen between 4 – 8 weeks.

 

Option C. Hegar's sign: On bimanual exam, the abdominal and vaginal fingers appose below the body of the uterus, seen between 6 – 10 weeks.

 

Option D. Osiander's sign: Increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, seen between 6 – 8 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Named Pelvic signs

 

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg168, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74

questions.text: Which of the following is an abnormal cardiovascular system examination finding during pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diastolic murmur

 

During pregnancy, several cardiovascular changes occur as normal physiological adaptations. However, a diastolic murmur is never considered normal and always requires further evaluation. Any diastolic murmur detected during pregnancy needs thorough investigation as it may indicate underlying cardiac pathology.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Soft systolic murmur: Incorrect because systolic murmurs are commonly heard during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output. They are considered a normal physiological finding.

 

Option C. S3 (Third heart sound): Incorrect because S3 can be heard as a normal finding during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and ventricular filling.

 

Option D. Loud S1 (First heart sound): Incorrect because a loud S1 is a normal cardiovascular finding during pregnancy due to changes in cardiac position and increased blood flow.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While systolic murmurs, S3, and loud S1 are normal cardiovascular examination findings in pregnancy, any diastolic murmur is always pathological and requires evaluation.

choices.text: Compression of the inferior vena cava
Compression of the superior vena cava

questions.text: A pregnant woman has dizziness on lying down straight and this improves when she turns to one side. A possible explanation is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Compression of the inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The scenario described is characteristic of supine hypotensive syndrome, which occurs when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back, causing the gravid uterus to compress the inferior vena cava (IVC). This compression decreases venous return to the heart, leading to reduced cardiac output and subsequent hypotension and dizziness.

 

Symptoms of dizziness and hypotension improve when the woman turns to her side (Left tilt), relieving the compression on the IVC.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Compression of the aorta: While the aorta can also be compressed, the primary issue in supine hypotensive syndrome is the reduced venous return due to IVC compression.

 

Option C. Compression of the superior vena cava: This is less likely to be affected by the position of the uterus during pregnancy.
 

Option D. Compression of the pulmonary vessels: This is not typically related to positional changes during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine hypotensive syndrome is caused by the compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus when a pregnant woman lies flat on her back. This condition is relieved by turning to one side, which reduces the compression and improves venous return to the heart.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

The correct matching of the procedures with their respective characteristics is as follows:

 

  • Amniocentesis (A-4): This procedure involves the assessment of amniotic fluid, often for detecting alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and other genetic conditions. It is generally performed between 15-18 weeks but may be done later as well.
  • Chorionic Villous Sampling (B-1): CVS is performed earlier in pregnancy, typically between 10-13 weeks. It involves sampling of placental tissue to test for chromosomal abnormalities and genetic conditions.
  • Fetal Blood Sampling (C-2): Also known as cordocentesis or percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), this procedure is done around 19-20 weeks to obtain fetal blood, often for testing fetal anemia, infections, or genetic conditions.
  • Fetoscopy (D-3): This procedure involves visualizing the fetus directly in utero and is used in specific circumstances to assess fetal anatomy and perform interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1: Incorrect because Chorionic Villous Sampling (CVS) is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetoscopy does not typically involve amniotic fluid assessment.

 

Option B. A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not done at 19-20 weeks, and fetal blood sampling is not done at 8-12 weeks.

 

Option D. A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1: Incorrect because Amniocentesis is not used to visualize fetal organs, and Chorionic Villous Sampling is not done at 19-20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the appropriate timing and purpose of various prenatal diagnostic procedures such as Amniocentesis, Chorionic Villous Sampling, Fetal Blood Sampling, and Fetoscopy.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 882, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 741

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 12 weeks of gestation comes to the antenatal clinic for nutritional advice. Which of the following will you recommend? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Additional 300kcal in 2nd trimester

 

Explanation:

 

  • For a pregnant woman, additional caloric intake recommendations vary by trimester.
  • As per Williams Obstetrics:
    • In the first trimester, no extra calories are required.
    • In the second trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 340 kcal per day.
    • In the third trimester, it is recommended to increase by approximately 452 kcal per day.
  • According to the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), an additional intake of 300 kcal during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy is recommended.
  • Therefore, the recommendation of an additional 300 kcal in the second trimester is appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Additional 300kcal in 1st trimester: No extra calories are recommended in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Additional 300kcal in 3rd trimester: The recommendation for the third trimester is an increase of approximately 452 kcal per day.

 

Option D. Additional 300kcal throughout the pregnancy: Caloric requirements vary by trimester, with no extra calories needed in the first trimester, and specific increases for the second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the caloric requirements and recommendations for each trimester of pregnancy to ensure adequate maternal and fetal nutrition.

 

Ref: Page 483, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

The clinical scenario presented indicates an unruptured ectopic pregnancy. The patient is hemodynamically stable, and the hCG level is 2800 IU/L with an adnexal mass measuring 3 x 2 cm. These findings meet the criteria for medical management of an ectopic pregnancy with methotrexate. Single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate treatment choice for an unruptured ectopic pregnancy when the patient is stable, has no significant symptoms, and the gestational sac is less than 3.5 cm in size without visible cardiac activity. Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis and cell replication, effectively treating the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Oral methotrexate is not a standard treatment protocol for ectopic pregnancy. Methotrexate for ectopic pregnancy is typically administered via injection to ensure proper dosage and effectiveness.

 

Option C. Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue: This multidose protocol is used for ectopic pregnancies with higher hCG levels or when the single-dose protocol is contraindicated or has failed. However, it is more complex and involves multiple injections and monitoring.

 

Option D. Salpingectomy: Surgical management, such as salpingectomy, is indicated for ectopic pregnancies with significant pain, adnexal masses larger than 35 mm, visible fetal heartbeat, or serum hCG levels of 5000 IU/L or more. In this case, the patient’s condition does not meet these criteria, making surgery unnecessary.

 

Management of Unruptured Ectopic

 

 

Surgical Management in Unruptured Ectopic –

 

Indicated in:

 

  1. an ectopic pregnancy and significant pain
  2. an ectopic pregnancy with an adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger
  3. an ectopic pregnancy with a fetal heartbeat visible on an ultrasound scan
  4. an ectopic pregnancy and a serum hCG level of 5,000 IU/L or more

 

 Laparoscopy is preferred

 

  1. SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube
    • Completed family
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization
  2. SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception) Done if a woman wants to conceive in the future.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy in a hemodynamically stable patient with an hCG level less than 5000 IU/L and an adnexal mass smaller than 3.5 cm is typically treated with a single-dose methotrexate injection.

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.

 

  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.

 

Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.

 

Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

questions.text: During pregnancy, pyogenic granuloma, also called granuloma gravidarum, most commonly arises from which location? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gingival papillae

 

Granuloma gravidarum (pyogenic granuloma) is a common gingival change during pregnancy. This highly vascular pedunculated lesion develops on the gums and may bleed profusely, which is why it's also known as epulis gravidarum. The condition develops due to hormonal changes of pregnancy, particularly increased estrogen levels causing increased vascularity and inflammatory response in the gingival tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tongue: Pyogenic granuloma during pregnancy specifically affects the gingival tissue, not the tongue. While oral changes do occur during pregnancy, the tongue is not the characteristic site for granuloma gravidarum.

 

Option C. Uvula: The uvula is not a typical site for pregnancy-related pyogenic granuloma. These vascular lesions specifically develop on the gingival tissue due to hormonal influences on gum vascularity.

 

Option D. Soft Palate: Soft palate involvement is not characteristic of granuloma gravidarum. These lesions have a predilection for the gingival tissue where they appear as red, bleeding masses on the gums.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma gravidarum (pregnancy epulis) is a highly vascular pedunculated lesion that develops on the gingiva during pregnancy and has a propensity to bleed profusely due to increased vascularity from hormonal changes.

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Linea Nigra

 

Explanation:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stria gravidarum: Stria gravidarum is a reddish stria of present pregnancy.

 

Option B. Linea Alba: The midline of the anterior abdominal wall skin. It takes on dark brown-black pigmentation to form the linea nigra.

 

 Option D. Stria albicans: Stria albicans is a silvery stria of previous pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A hyperpigmented line from xiphisternum to pubic symphysis is Linea Nigra.

 

Ref: Page no 79, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Pre- invasive diagnostic test

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue pregnancy

 

Explanation

 

  • The risks for malformations, growth restriction, or abortion are not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).
  • Since diagnostic X-rays seldom exceed 0.1 Gy (10 rads), the risk is negligible. A 0.1 Gy exposure is equivalent to more than 1000 chest X-rays.
  • Hence, continuing pregnancy is the most appropriate advice to this woman.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Terminate pregnancy: Termination is not necessary as the radiation dose from a single chest X-ray is significantly lower than the threshold for increased risks.

 

Option C. Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This is not required in this scenario as the radiation dose is too low to justify invasive diagnostics.

 

Option D. Chromosome screening: Chromosome screening is unnecessary because the radiation dose from a chest X-ray does not significantly increase the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective

 

The risk for fetal malformations, growth restriction, or abortion is not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).

 

Ref: Page 2265, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

 

  • Gestational age or period of gestation (POG) refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of last menstrual period
  • Calculating the EDD: 
    • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
    • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day) 
      • Add 9 months + 7 days
      • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
      • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
    • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
      • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
      • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st trimester USG is the best assessment: Correct, because the 1st trimester USG provides the most accurate dating method.

 

Option C. In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG: Correct, because calculating gestational age in IVF pregnancies relies on the day of embryo transfer or fertilization.

 

Option D. Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester: Correct, because CRL is the best measure for assessing the period of gestation in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg127

questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 69 XXY

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are characterized by being triploid, meaning they have three sets of chromosomes. The chromosome number for a partial mole is typically 69, which can be either 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

  • Formation of Partial Mole:
    • Partial moles occur when two sperm fertilize a single ovum (egg). This process is called diandry.
    • As a result, both maternal and paternal genetic components are present in a partial mole.
    • The most common karyotypes for partial moles are 69XXX and 69XXY.
  • Complete Mole Characteristics:
    • Complete moles are diploid, meaning they have two sets of chromosomes.
    • They form either by:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum and then undergoing duplication, a process known as androgenesis, or
      • Two sperm (dispermy) fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum.
    • The chromosome number for complete moles is typically 46XX or 46XY.
    • Only the paternal genetic component is present, with no maternal contribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 46 XX: This karyotype is typical for a complete mole, not a partial mole.

 

Option B. 45 XY: This karyotype is not typical for either complete or partial moles.

 

Option C. 69 XY: This option is incorrect as partial moles can be 69XY, but 69XXY is more specific and typical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial hydatidiform moles are triploid, typically having a chromosome number of 69, which can be 69XXX or 69XXY.

 

Ref: Page no 616, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: At what period of gestation is the nuchal translucency measured? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11-14 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Nuchal translucency (NT) measurement is an ultrasound marker used for the screening of chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome (trisomy 21). The optimal time to measure NT is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation, more specifically between 11 weeks and 13 weeks and 6 days. During this period, the NT measurement is most accurate and predictive. The NT scan involves measuring the clear space in the tissue at the back of the baby's neck.

 

An absent Nasal Bone (NB) and increased NT measurement both are the marker of Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Nuchal translucency should be measured between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation to effectively screen for chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampulla

 

Explanation

 

Ectopic pregnancy refers to implantation occurring outside the endometrial cavity.

 

Sites of implantation

 

 

Uterine (.5%) such as cervical (1%), caesarean scar ectopic <1%)

 

Management of tubal ectopic may be medical or surgical: medical management maybe considered if the patient is haemodynamically stable , foetal cardiac activity absent, beta HCG level less than 5000 , size of gestational sac less than 4 cm .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infundibulum: Accounts for 18% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option C. Isthmus: Accounts for 25% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option D. Interstitial portion: Accounts for 2% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Management of Tubal Ectopic Pregnancy:

 

Management may be medical or surgical:

 

  • Medical Management: Considered if the patient is hemodynamically stable, fetal cardiac activity is absent, beta HCG level is less than 5000, and the size of the gestational sac is less than 4 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy, accounting for 55% of cases.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of obstetrics page 207

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with delayed periods and vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals retained products of conception, and a suction evacuation is performed. The extracted tissue is sent for histopathology, which reports a karyotype of 46XX and is p57kip2 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete mole

 

The diagnosis is complete mole based on two key findings:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX) - Complete moles typically have a diploid karyotype
  2. p57kip2 negative staining - p57kip2 is a paternally imprinted, maternally expressed gene. Its negative expression is diagnostic of complete mole as there is no maternal genetic material

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Partial mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • Partial moles have triploid karyotype (69XXX or 69XXY)
  • p57kip2 is positive in partial moles due to presence of maternal genetic material

 

Option C. Invasive mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a complication of molar pregnancy where the mole invades the myometrium
  • Diagnosis requires imaging evidence of myometrial invasion
  • Karyotype alone cannot diagnose invasive mole

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Diagnosis is based on histopathology showing malignant trophoblastic tissue
  • Cannot be diagnosed by karyotype and p57kip2 staining alone

 

Educational Objective: 

 

complete molar pregnancy is characterized by:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX)
  2. Negative p57kip2 staining
  3. Complete absence of maternal genetic material

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibrinogen

 

Explanation:

 

Pregnancy is characterized as a hypercoagulable state, and several changes occur in the coagulation system during pregnancy. One of the significant changes is the increase in fibrinogen levels, which leads to a rise in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR.
  • ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin.
  • Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester.
  • Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased.
  • Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy.
  • Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Albumin levels typically decrease during pregnancy due to hemodilution, and they do not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option B. Platelet: Platelet count may slightly decrease due to gestational thrombocytopenia, but this does not contribute to the rise in ESR.

 

Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody: This is not a relevant factor in the context of ESR increase during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during pregnancy is primarily due to the increased levels of fibrinogen.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg59

choices.text: Left axis deviation
Mild ST changes in inferior leads
Atrial and ventricular premature contractions
Pansystolic murmur

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pansystolic murmur

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, there are several physiological changes in the cardiovascular system:

 

  1. Clinical Examination:
    • Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed.
    • Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces.
    • Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas.
    • Increased and widely split S1 sound.
    • S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split.
    • The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  2. Electrocardiography:
    • T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement.
    • Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent.
    • Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
    • Pregnancy does not alter voltage.
    • Tricuspid regurgitation may be present.
    • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left axis deviation: This is a normal change due to the diaphragm being elevated during pregnancy, causing an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the ECG.

 

Option B. Mild ST changes in inferior leads: These are normal and can be seen due to the changes in heart position and function during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: These are relatively frequent and considered normal in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diastolic and pansystolic murmurs in pregnancy are not normal and should be investigated further.

 

Ref: Page 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Follow up with beta-hCG
Suction and evacuation

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

 

Explanation:

 

The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.

 

Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

 

Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 614

choices.text: Decreased number of Lactobacilli
Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium
pH > 6.8
Epithelial thinning

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

 

  • Vaginal epithelium increases the metabolism of glycogen in pregnancy.
  • It leads to decrease in pH and makes the vaginal epithelium more acidic
  • This is because of increased lactobacilli

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased number of Lactobacilli: The number of lactobacilli are increased in the reproductive age group especially in pregnancy

 

Option C. pH > 6.8: Vaginal pH in pregnancy is acidic

 

 

Option D. Epithelial thinning: Estrogen increases the vaginal thickness in pregnancy. The vagina becomes thin in the absence of estrogen (like in menopause)

 

Educational Objective:

 

During pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium increases glycogen metabolism, leading to a more acidic environment that promotes the growth of Lactobacilli and helps protect against infections.

 

Ref: Page no 20, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition
