﻿﻿﻿Missed abortion
﻿﻿﻿Ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatidiform mole

 

Explanation:


The typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’ on ultrasound is indicative of a hydatidiform mole. This appearance is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy, where there is a proliferation of abnormal tissue instead of a viable embryo.

 

  • Complete Mole:
    • Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity.
    • Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY.
      • Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
    • Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • Partial Mole:
    • Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum.
    • Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blighted ovum: Also known as an anembryonic pregnancy, this occurs when a gestational sac forms but no embryo is visible. It does not present with the Snowstorm appearance and usually lacks the pronounced proliferation of tissue seen in a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option B. Missed abortion: This involves the retention of an embryo or fetus with no detectable heartbeat or growth. The ultrasound findings typically show a non-viable fetus without the characteristic snowstorm pattern of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: This occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tubes. It would not present with the Snowstorm appearance but rather show a gestational sac or products of conception in an abnormal location.

 

Educational Objective:


The 'Snowstorm appearance' on transvaginal ultrasound is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Ref: Page no 225, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents at 8 weeks of pregnancy. During the examination, a specific clinical sign is observed. What is the name of the sign being elicited? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hegar sign

 

The image demonstrates Hegar's sign, which is elicited during bimanual examination in early pregnancy. Due to the softening of the lower uterine segment at the level of the isthmus, the examining fingers can be approximated between the cervix and the uterine body. This softening allows the examiner's hands to almost meet at the isthmus level during bimanual examination, which is characteristic of Hegar's sign.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Palmer sign: This is incorrect. Palmer sign refers to the detection of subtle uterine contractions felt during bimanual examination in early pregnancy, not the softening at isthmus.

 

Option C. Internal ballotment: This is incorrect. Internal ballotment is a second-trimester finding (after 16 weeks) where the fetus can be balloted between the examining fingers during vaginal examination.

 

Option D. External ballotment: This is incorrect. External ballotment is also a second-trimester finding elicited through abdominal examination, not applicable at 8 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hegar's sign as the softening of the lower uterine segment at the isthmus level during early pregnancy, allowing approximation of examining fingers during bimanual examination, and distinguishing it from other pregnancy signs.

choices.text: Placental site trophoblastic tumor
Invasive mole

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm does not include? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial mole

 

Explanation:

 

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) includes a spectrum of conditions characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation. These conditions are broadly classified into molar and non-molar trophoblastic diseases.

 

  • Hydatidiform Mole:
    • Complete Mole
    • Partial Mole
    • Invasive Mole
  • Non-Molar Trophoblastic Diseases:
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
    • Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN), on the other hand, includes only the malignant forms of trophoblastic disease:

 

  1. Invasive Mole
  2. Choriocarcinoma
  3. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor
  4. Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumor

 

A partial mole is a type of hydatidiform mole and is considered benign. It is not included under GTN as it does not have malignant potential unless it transforms into an invasive mole, which is rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Choriocarcinoma: This is a malignant form of GTD and is classified under GTN.

 

Option C. Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor: This is another malignant form of GTD and is included under GTN.

 

Option D. Invasive Mole: An invasive mole is a malignant transformation of a hydatidiform mole and is included under GTN.

 

Educational Objective

 

Partial moles are not classified as gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) because they are generally benign and non-malignant.

 

Ref: Page no 615, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: When is the quadruple marker test done? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 16 – 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

The quadruple marker test is a prenatal screening test performed during the second trimester of pregnancy, typically between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation.

 

This test is used to assess the risk of certain genetic disorders, including Down syndrome (trisomy 21), trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

 

The quadruple marker test measures four specific substances in the mother's blood:

 

  1. Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  2. Free beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (free beta-HCG)
  3. Inhibin A
  4. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

 

These markers provide information about the likelihood of certain fetal abnormalities.

 

Note - In the case of Down syndrome, free beta-HCG and inhibin A levels tend to be elevated, while unconjugated estriol and alpha-fetoprotein levels are typically decreased.

 

Educational objective:

 

The quadruple marker test is conducted between 16 and 20 weeks of gestation to screen for genetic disorders such as Down syndrome, trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

choices.text: 10 to 12 weeks
8 to 10 weeks

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.

 

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:

 

  • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • Severe: <7 g%

 

Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia

 

  • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe Anemia

 

  • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 to 12 weeks: While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.

 

Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.

 

Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

choices.text: Functional residual capacity
Inspiratory capacity

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration. During pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated due to the enlarging uterus, leading to a decrease in FRC by approximately 22%. This is primarily due to reductions in expiratory reserve volume and residual volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate: The respiratory rate typically remains unchanged during pregnancy, staying at about 14-16 breaths per minute.

 

Option B. Vital capacity: Vital capacity, which is the sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume, remains unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Inspiratory capacity increases during pregnancy by about 10%. This increase is due to the higher tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity decreases during pregnancy due to the elevation of the diaphragm caused by the enlarging uterus.

 

  • Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: Page no 189, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days
Admit and observe
Follow-up with beta-HCG

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

 

The patient presents with symptoms that could indicate either an ectopic pregnancy or an early miscarriage. The absence of a gestational sac in the uterus on ultrasound at 6 weeks' gestation warrants further investigation to determine the location and viability of the pregnancy. The most appropriate next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ectopic Pregnancy vs. Early Miscarriage: The differential diagnosis includes both ectopic pregnancy and early miscarriage.
  • Serial Beta-HCG Measurement: Beta-HCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours in a normal early intrauterine pregnancy. An abnormal rise or plateau in beta-HCG levels may indicate an ectopic pregnancy or a failing pregnancy.
  • Ultrasound Follow-up: In combination with beta-HCG monitoring, follow-up ultrasounds can help determine if a gestational sac becomes visible in the uterus or elsewhere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days: Declaring a complete abortion without further investigation is premature and may miss an ectopic pregnancy, which can have serious complications.

 

Option B. Admit and observe: While observation is important, serial beta-HCG levels provide critical information that can guide further management decisions.

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure and is not the first step in stable patients without definitive evidence of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 356

choices.text: Previous manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Previous manual removal of placenta

 

Explanation:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta does not automatically categorize a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk. High-risk pregnancies are characterized by various factors that may complicate the pregnancy or pose risks to the mother and fetus. These factors include existing health conditions, certain lifestyle factors, age-related risks, and specific pregnancy conditions.

 

High-risk pregnancy factors according to the NIH include:

 

  1. Existing health conditions:
    • Hypertension
    • Diabetes
    • Autoimmune diseases
    • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome)
    • Thyroid disorders
    • Obesity
    • HIV
    • Anemia
    • Uterine fibroids
  2. Age:
    • Adolescence
    • First-time pregnancy at age >35 years
  3. Lifestyle factors:
    • Alcohol consumption
    • Smoking
    • Drug use
  4. Pregnancy conditions:
    • Multiple pregnancy
    • Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)
    • Pre-eclampsia
    • Previous preterm birth
    • Congenital or chromosomal anomalies
    • Polyhydramnios or oligohydramnios
    • Rh iso-immunization
    • Antepartum hemorrhage
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: Obesity is a significant factor for a high-risk pregnancy as it is associated with various complications such as gestational diabetes, pre-eclampsia, and increased risk of cesarean delivery.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, which is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, can lead to complications such as preterm labor and fetal malformations, making it a high-risk condition.

 

Option C. Anemia: Anemia during pregnancy can affect the health of both the mother and the fetus, leading to conditions such as preterm birth and low birth weight, thus categorizing it as high-risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Previous manual removal of the placenta is not considered a factor for categorizing a subsequent pregnancy as high-risk.

 

Ref: https://www.nichd.nih.gov/health/topics/high-risk

questions.text: The earliest sign of pregnancy on Trans Vaginal Scan is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gestational sac

 

On transvaginal ultrasound (TVS), the gestational sac is the first visible sign of pregnancy, appearing at 5 weeks of gestation. This is approximately one week earlier than when it becomes visible on transabdominal scan (TAS, visible at 6 weeks). The gestational sac appears as an anechoic structure within the endometrial cavity.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Yolk sac: This is incorrect as the yolk sac appears at 5.5 weeks on TVS, after the gestational sac is visible.

 

Option C. Fetal pole: This is incorrect as the fetal pole appears at 6 weeks on TVS, after both the gestational sac and yolk sac are visible.

 

Option D. Cardiac activity: This is incorrect as cardiac activity also becomes visible at 6 weeks on TVS, along with the fetal pole, making it one of the later findings in early pregnancy ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The chronological order of appearance of early pregnancy structures on TVS:

 

  • Gestational sac: 5 weeks
  • Yolk sac: 5.5 weeks
  • Fetal pole with cardiac activity: 6 weeks 
  • On trans-abdominal scan; these structures appear 1 week later

questions.text: Home based urine pregnancy tests detect which hormone? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

Home-based urine pregnancy tests detect human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), specifically the beta subunit of hCG (β-hCG).

 

  • hCG is the earliest detectable hormone in pregnancy
  • hCG is secreted by the trophoblastic cells of the developing placenta soon after implantation, which occurs approximately 6-10 days post-fertilization.
  • The hormone helps maintain the corpus luteum, ensuring continued progesterone production to support early pregnancy.
  • Urine pregnancy tests typically detect hCG levels at or above 20-25 mIU/mL, allowing for early pregnancy confirmation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone): This is a pituitary hormone involved in follicular development and not specific to pregnancy. It is not used for pregnancy detection as its levels fluctuate throughout the menstrual cycle.

 

Option C. Estrogen: While estrogen levels do increase during pregnancy, it is not specific enough for pregnancy detection as it is also present during normal menstrual cycles.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Although progesterone levels rise during pregnancy, it is not used in home pregnancy tests as it is also present during the luteal phase of menstrual cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Home pregnancy tests specifically detect the beta subunit of hCG in urine for pregnancy diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crown rump length

 

Explanation:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Biparietal diameter, B. Head circumference and D. Abdominal circumference are parameters useful in second trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crown rump length is the best parameter for estimating fetal age during the first trimester using ultrasound.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition page 84

questions.text: What is altered in thyroid profile throughout pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total T3 level

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the thyroid profile undergoes several changes due to physiological adaptations. One significant change is the increase in total T3 and T4 levels. This occurs because of the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), which increases the amount of bound thyroid hormones. Despite this increase, the levels of free T3 and free T4 remain relatively unchanged.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG): The production of TBG increases during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels. This leads to higher levels of total T3 and total T4.
  • Free T3 and Free T4: Despite the increase in total hormone levels, the free (unbound) hormone levels remain relatively stable. This is why free T3 and free T4 are preferred for thyroid function testing during pregnancy.
  • TSH: The levels of TSH may decrease slightly in the first trimester due to the thyrotropic effects of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), but they generally stabilize in the second and third trimesters.
  • Iodine requirement: Pregnancy increases the body's requirement for iodine by about 50%, due to increased renal clearance and fetal iodine needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Free T3 level: This remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Free T4 level: This also remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. TSH level: While TSH levels can decrease slightly in the first trimester, they typically stabilize throughout the rest of the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, total T3 and T4 levels increase due to elevated thyroid-binding globulin, while free T3 and T4 levels remain unchanged.

 

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: A 22y female is overdue by 2 weeks. She visits the OPD with complaints of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain on the right side. On Examination, her vitals are stable. Abdomen examination is unremarkable. A bimanual examination reveals a bulky, soft uterus with no tenderness and no adnexal mass. Mild bleeding +. Beta hCG is 1400 IU. An ultrasound reveals a trilaminar endometrium, and both the adnexa are normal. The next best step is?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat serum beta HCG after 48h

 

Explanation:

 

  • Repeat serum beta hCG after 48h:
    • The clinical scenario suggests a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), which could either be a failing intrauterine pregnancy or an ectopic pregnancy.
    • The best next step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours. A rise in beta hCG by at least 66% would suggest a viable intrauterine pregnancy, while a plateau or drop would indicate a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure and is not the immediate next step in the management of a stable patient with PUL. It is reserved for cases where there is a high suspicion of ectopic pregnancy with unstable vital signs or inconclusive non-invasive tests.

 

Option C. Repeat USG after 3 days: Repeating the ultrasound after 3 days may not provide additional useful information if the initial ultrasound did not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Monitoring beta hCG levels first is more informative and guides the need for further imaging.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: Simply waiting without further evaluation could delay diagnosis and appropriate management, especially in the case of a potential ectopic pregnancy, which can be life-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), the next best step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours to differentiate between a viable intrauterine pregnancy and a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

choices.text: Echocardiography for cardiac disease
Urine analysis for bacteriuria
Blood sugar levels for GDM
VDRL for syphilis

questions.text: The following cost-effective investigations are routinely recommended in the screening of antenatal mothers except? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echocardiography for cardiac disease

 

Explanation:

 

Echocardiography for cardiac disease is not part of routine antenatal screening. While it is important for detecting cardiac conditions, echocardiography is typically performed only if there is a known or suspected cardiac disease. Routine screening for all antenatal mothers does not include echocardiography due to its cost and the specific indications required for its use.

 

Routine antenatal screening is designed to identify common conditions that may affect the health of the mother and baby.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Urine analysis for bacteriuriaUrine analysis for bacteriuria: This test is routinely performed to detect asymptomatic bacteriuria, which, if left untreated, can lead to urinary tract infections and increase the risk of preterm labor.

 

Option C. Blood sugar levels for GDM Blood sugar levels for GDM (Gestational Diabetes Mellitus): Screening for GDM is essential to identify women who develop diabetes during pregnancy, which can affect both maternal and fetal health.

 

Option D. VDRL for syphilis: The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a screening tool for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection that can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby if left untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine antenatal screening does not include echocardiography for cardiac disease unless there is a known or suspected condition.

 

Ref: Page no 110, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version

questions.text: A 34 year G2P1 presents at 35 weeks. She has no complaints and is appreciating fetal movements well. She had a previous classical cesarean at 25 weeks for eclampsia and severe FGR. She is currently on low dose aspirin and prenatal vitamins. On examination, the uterus is SFH is 38 cm and FHR is 140 bpm. An ultrasound reveals a single live fetus in breech presentation, placenta posterior and amniotic fluid normal. The patient desires a vaginal delivery. What is the best management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Schedule elective LSCS at 37 weeks:
    • The patient has a history of a classical cesarean section, which is an absolute contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture.
    • A classical cesarean section involves a vertical incision on the upper part of the uterus, which does not heal as strongly as the lower segment horizontal incision, leading to a higher risk of rupture during labor.
    • Given the breech presentation and the patient's obstetric history, an elective cesarean section at 37 weeks is the safest option to prevent complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Review USG after 2 weeks: This option does not address the critical issue of the patient's previous classical cesarean section, which necessitates planning for a repeat cesarean delivery.

 

Option C. ECV at 36 weeks: External Cephalic Version (ECV) is contraindicated in patients with a previous classical cesarean section due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.

 

Option D. Await spontaneous labor and then do an internal podalic version: Awaiting spontaneous labor is not advisable due to the increased risk of uterine rupture with a classical cesarean scar. Additionally, internal podalic version is not a recommended procedure in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A classical cesarean section is an absolute contraindication to a vaginal delivery due to the high risk of uterine rupture; hence, an elective cesarean section should be scheduled at 37 weeks.

 

Ref: Page no 1439, William Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of 2 months of amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is positive. On speculum examination, the following finding is observed. Identify the sign seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chadwick’s sign

 

The image shows a speculum examination of the cervix demonstrating a bluish/purplish discoloration, which is known as Chadwick's sign or Jacquemier's sign. This is one of the earliest visible signs of pregnancy, caused by increased vascularity and venous congestion of the cervix and vagina during early pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Osiander sign: This is incorrect. Osiander sign refers to the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity of uterine arteries in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Hegar sign: This is incorrect. Hegar sign is elicited during bimanual examination where there is softening of the lower uterine segment, allowing the examiner's fingers to almost meet between the cervix and uterine body.

 

Option D. Placental sign: This is incorrect. Placental sign refers to implantation bleeding that occurs when the embryo implants in the uterus.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chadwick's sign (bluish discoloration of cervix and vagina) as one of the early visible signs of pregnancy during speculum examination, distinguishing it from other early pregnancy signs like Hegar's and Osiander's signs.

questions.text: A high dose of folic acid should be given pre-conceptionally in women with? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Poorly controlled diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

A high dose of folic acid is recommended pre-conceptionally for women who are at a higher risk of neural tube defects. This includes women with poorly controlled diabetes, which is associated with an increased risk of congenital abnormalities, including neural tube defects. A high dose of folic acid (4 to 5 mg daily) should be started at least three months before conception to reduce this risk and to be given till 16 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Previous h/o preeclampsia: The preventive strategy for women with a history of preeclampsia includes the use of low-dose aspirin (Ecosprin), not high-dose folic acid.

 

Option B. Previous preterm delivery: Management includes progesterone supplementation or considering a cervical cerclage in cases of cervical insufficiency, rather than high-dose folic acid.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: While folic acid is important in hemoglobinopathies, the primary concern in sickle cell anemia is maintaining adequate folic acid levels due to increased hemolysis, but it is not specifically indicated at high doses for pre-conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Women with poorly controlled diabetes, epileptics, should receive a high dose of folic acid pre-conceptionally to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

questions.text: Marker for ectopic pregnancy is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

The correct answer is Beta hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin). Beta hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta during pregnancy. In the context of an ectopic pregnancy, which is a pregnancy located outside the uterine cavity (commonly in the fallopian tubes), the measurement of Beta hCG levels is crucial for diagnosis and management.

 

Beta hCG: In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, Beta hCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours. In ectopic pregnancies, these levels usually rise more slowly. Additionally, Beta hCG levels are used to determine the mode of management for unruptured ectopic pregnancies (medical, surgical, or expectant management) and to assess the discriminatory zone, which is the level of Beta hCG at which an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estradiol: This is a form of estrogen, a hormone involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy, but it is not a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option C. Progesterone: This hormone supports the early stages of pregnancy by preparing the uterine lining for implantation, but it is not specifically used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Estriol: Another form of estrogen produced during pregnancy, it is not used as a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is the primary marker used to diagnose and manage ectopic pregnancies, providing essential information about pregnancy location and viability.

choices.text: Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass
Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2 presents with delayed menstrual cycles, mild abdominal pain, and vaginal bleeding. A urine pregnancy test is positive. What are the ultrasound features suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Empty uterus with adnexal mass and fluid in pelvis

 

In ectopic pregnancy, transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation. The most characteristic finding is an empty uterine cavity with a mass in the adnexa  and fluid collection in the pelvis. The fluid represents blood from either tubal abortion or rupture, which typically collects in the pouch of Douglas behind the uterus. These findings together strongly suggest an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Thin endometrium with no adnexal mass: Incorrect because in ectopic pregnancy, the presence of an adnexal mass is a key diagnostic feature. Without an adnexal mass, the diagnosis is incomplete.

 

Option C. Intra uterine gestational sac: Incorrect as this finding indicates a normal intrauterine pregnancy, not an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Thick endometrium: Incorrect because this finding alone is nonspecific and can be seen in various conditions. It does not help diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The classic ultrasound findings in ectopic pregnancy are:

 

1. Empty uterine cavity

 

2. Adnexal mass (Bagel sign/ Blob sign)

 

3. Gestational sac with yolk sav/ fetal pole in the adnexa

 

4. Ring of fire on Doppler

 

 

5. Free fluid in the pelvis (representing blood from abortion or rupture)

questions.text: Which of the following aneuploidies is most likely to be missed in prenatal neonatal screening? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klinefelter's Syndrome

 

Klinefelter's Syndrome is most likely to be missed in prenatal neonatal screening. Standard prenatal screening protocols primarily target trisomies 21, 18, and 13, as well as Turner's syndrome. The highly effective first trimester combined screening (nuchal translucency with serum markers β-hCG and PAPP-A) and cell-free DNA testing are designed to detect these specific conditions. Klinefelter's Syndrome (47, XXY) is not prominently featured in the standard screening algorithms discussed in prenatal care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome): This is actually the most commonly screened aneuploidy. The detection rate is extremely high - 99% with cell-free DNA testing and 85-92% with combined first trimester screening. First trimester screening shows increased β-hCG, decreased PAPP-A, and increased nuchal translucency in Down syndrome

.

Option B. Trisomy 18 (Edwards' syndrome): This is specifically included in standard screening protocols. It presents with decreased β-hCG and decreased PAPP-A in first trimester screening, with a high detection rate using combined screening approaches.

 

Option C. Turner's Syndrome (Monosomy X): This is reliably detected through nuchal thickness screening. Monosomy X (45,XO) is the "single most frequent specific chromosomal anomaly" comprising 9-13% of chromosomal abnormalities detected in spontaneous abortions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While prenatal screening programs effectively detect the common trisomies (21, 18, 13) and Turner syndrome through combined approaches, Klinefelter's Syndrome is less emphasized in standard screening protocols, making it more likely to be missed in routine prenatal screening.

questions.text: A woman presents with bleeding since 2 days and abdominal pain. Her LMP was 6 weeks back. An ultrasound shows fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

The correct answer is Ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition is an emergency where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube. As the pregnancy grows, it can cause the tube to rupture, leading to internal bleeding. The classic presentation of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy includes:

 

  • Abdominal pain: Due to the rupture and internal bleeding.
  • Vaginal bleeding: Occurs as a result of the ectopic pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea (missed period): Indicates an early pregnancy.
  • Fluid in the pouch of Douglas: This is a key diagnostic clue. The pouch of Douglas is the lowest point of the female pelvis, located between the uterus and the rectum. In the case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, blood often collects here, visible as fluid on an ultrasound.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, typically occurring in the third trimester. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a rigid, tender uterus. This scenario does not fit the description of the early pregnancy situation described in the question.

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This condition occurs when the placenta covers the cervix either partially or completely. It typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester, not in the first trimester as described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Missed abortion: A missed abortion refers to a situation where the fetus has died but has not been expelled from the uterus. It usually presents with an absence of fetal heart tones on ultrasound and a uterus that is smaller than expected for gestational age. There would not typically be fluid in the pouch of Douglas, which is more indicative of intraperitoneal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, if a patient presents with abdominal pain, bleeding, and a history of missed periods, with fluid in the pouch of Douglas seen on ultrasound, the most likely diagnosis is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. This condition requires immediate surgical intervention.

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It can be confirmatory test of trisomy 13, 18 and 21

 

Explanation:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool, not a diagnostic tool. It uses cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal serum to screen for certain genetic conditions, including trisomies 13, 18, and 21.

 

NIPT is not used for diagnosis but for screening. It has high sensitivity (about 99%) for detecting trisomies 21, 18, and 13, but positive results must be confirmed with diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum: Correct. NIPT uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain genetic conditions in the fetus.

 

Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation: Correct. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation, when there is enough fetal DNA in the maternal blood for accurate analysis.

 

Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment: Correct. NIPT is often done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment, which helps determine gestational age and detect multiple pregnancies or major anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test for aneuploidy using cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum, typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which hormone is increased in the condition shown in the image?  (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) hCG

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the classic "snowstorm" appearance seen on ultrasound, which is characteristic of a molar pregnancy, specifically a complete mole. In a complete molar pregnancy, there is abnormal trophoblastic proliferation and hydropic degeneration of chorionic villi, leading to the absence of fetal tissue and the characteristic ultrasound appearance.

 

The key hormone that is markedly elevated in molar pregnancy is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). This hormone is produced in excessive amounts due to the trophoblastic proliferation. The extremely high levels of hCG are responsible for many of the symptoms and complications associated with molar pregnancies, such as hyperemesis gravidarum, early-onset preeclampsia, and ovarian theca-lutein cysts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): This hormone is involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and ovulation but is not specifically elevated in molar pregnancy.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Levels of estrogen can be altered in pregnancy and other conditions but are not specifically elevated in molar pregnancy.

 

Option D. Progesterone: This hormone supports pregnancy, but its levels are not specifically elevated due to molar pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hormone significantly elevated in molar pregnancy, as indicated by the ultrasound image showing a "snowstorm" appearance, is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 8

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) updated its guidelines in 2016, recommending a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality. This guideline is structured to ensure comprehensive monitoring and support throughout the pregnancy:

 

  1. 1st Trimester:
    • Contact 1: up to 12 weeks
  2. 2nd Trimester:
    • Contact 2: at 20 weeks
    • Contact 3: at 26 weeks
  3. 3rd Trimester:
    • Contact 4: at 30 weeks
    • Contact 5: at 34 weeks
    • Contact 6: at 36 weeks
    • Contact 7: at 38 weeks
    • Contact 8: at 40 weeks

 

These visits are designed to monitor the health of the mother and fetus, provide timely interventions, and offer essential health education.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to improve pregnancy outcomes and reduce perinatal mortality.

 

Ref: The 2016 WHO model for positive pregnancy experience, MOHFW guidelines for antenatal care, ACOG guidelines for antenatal care (2017).

questions.text: Which vaccine is not safe in pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varicella

 

Varicella (chickenpox) vaccine is a live vaccine that is contraindicated during pregnancy. Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy due to the theoretical risk of transmitting the attenuated virus to the fetus, which could potentially cause infection and teratogenicity. The only exception to this rule is the yellow fever vaccine, which may be given if travel to an endemic area is absolutely necessary.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Influenza: Incorrect. While influenza vaccine is available in both live and inactivated forms, the inactivated influenza vaccine is commonly used and is safe during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Rabies: Incorrect. Rabies vaccine is a killed vaccine and is safe to administer during pregnancy if indicated.

 

Option D. Td: Incorrect. Tetanus and diphtheria (Td) vaccine is routinely recommended and safely administered during pregnancy to prevent maternal and neonatal tetanus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All live vaccines except yellow fever are contra-indicated due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection and teratogenicity

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Goodell's sign
  2. Osiander's sign
  3. Internal ballottement
  4. Lightening
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • Goodell's sign: This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation.
  • Osiander's sign: This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation.
  • Internal ballottement: This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix.
  • Lightening: This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 1, 3: Internal ballottement cannot be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation as it is typically felt between 16 and 28 weeks.

 

Option C. 1, 4: Lightening is not experienced until about 38 weeks of gestation, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. 3, 4: Neither internal ballottement nor lightening can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign (softening of the cervix) and Osiander's sign (increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices).

 

  • Signs in early pregnancy are as shown below

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74

questions.text: Patient experiences softening of the cervix in early pregnancy. This sign is called as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goodell

 

Goodell's sign refers to the softening of the cervix, which is observed during early pregnancy. This sign occurs due to increased vascularization and changes in the connective tissue of the cervix, making it feel softer compared to the non-pregnant state, where the cervix feels firm like the tip of the nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osiander: This is incorrect. Osiander’s sign refers to the palpable pulsation of the uterine arteries felt through the lateral fornices during a vaginal examination in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Chadwick: This is incorrect. Chadwick's sign, also known as Jacquemier’s sign, is the bluish discoloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix due to increased blood flow during early pregnancy.

 

Option D. Hegar: This is incorrect. Hegar's sign involves the softening of the lower uterine segment, which is palpable during a bimanual examination, allowing the examiner's fingers to approximate between the uterus and the cervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodell's sign is the softening of the cervix, observed in early pregnancy due to increased vascularity, which makes the cervix feel soft, like the lips, compared to its usual firm texture

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inj. methotrexate

 

Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy can include expectant, medical, or surgical approaches depending on the patient's condition and specific characteristics of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Medical Management (Single Dose Methotrexate):

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis, effectively treating ectopic pregnancies by stopping the growth of the trophoblastic tissue.
  • Indications for Methotrexate:
    • Patient hemodynamically stable.
    • No significant symptoms.
    • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm.
    • No visible cardiac activity.
    • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L.
    • No contraindication to Methotrexate.

 

In this scenario, the patient has a beta hCG level of 2800 mIU/mL, a 3 cm mass in the left adnexa, and no fetal cardiac activity, making her an appropriate candidate for single-dose methotrexate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management:

 

  • Indications:
    • Clinically stable with no pain.
    • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
    • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
    • Ability to return for follow-up.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's beta hCG level is 2800 mIU/mL and she presents with symptoms, thus expectant management is not suitable.

 

Option B. Salpingectomy:

 

  • Indications:
    • Significant pain.
    • Adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.
    • Visible fetal heartbeat on ultrasound.
    • Serum hCG level of 5000 IU/L or more.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's ectopic pregnancy size and beta hCG levels do not meet the criteria for surgical intervention. She is hemodynamically stable and a good candidate for medical management.

 

Option C. Milking of the tube:

 

  • Indications: Generally not a recommended procedure due to the risk of incomplete removal of trophoblastic tissue and subsequent complications.
  • Reason for not choosing: This option is outdated and not typically recommended for the management of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.

 

Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: What is the ideal number of antenatal visits? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12-14

 

Explanation:

 

The ideal number of antenatal visits as recommended by various guidelines:

 

  1. MOHFW (Indian guidelines):
    • At least 4 visits including the first (registration visit) – minimum requirement.
    • Suggested schedule:
      • 1st Visit: Within 12 weeks
      • 2nd Visit: 14-26 weeks
      • 3rd Visit: 28-34 weeks
      • 4th Visit: 36 weeks to term
  2. WHO (2016):
    • Recommends 8 visits:
      • 1st Trimester:
        • Contact 1: Up to 12 weeks
      • 2nd Trimester:
        • Contact 2: 20 weeks
        • Contact 3: 26 weeks
      • 3rd Trimester:
        • Contact 4: 30 weeks
        • Contact 5: 34 weeks
        • Contact 6: 36 weeks
        • Contact 7: 38 weeks
        • Contact 8: 40 weeks
  3. ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists):
    • Ideally recommends:
      • Once every month till 28 weeks
      • Every 2 weeks till 36 weeks
      • Weekly till 40 weeks
    • This totals approximately 12-14 visits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of antenatal visits is 12-14, as recommended by ACOG, ensuring comprehensive prenatal care.
